I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  During  the  2006  Country  Programming  Mission,  the  Government  of  the  People’s 
Republic of China (PRC) requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to help the Yancheng 
municipal government (YMG) of Jiangsu province to prepare the Jiangsu Yancheng Wetlands 
Protection Project. The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will design a project to 
meet the PRC’s goals of conserving natural ecosystems and addressing ADB’s overarching 
goals of poverty reduction and environmental sustainability.  
 
2.  At the request of the Government, ADB fielded a fact-finding mission in October 2007. 
The mission held discussions with representatives of the central, provincial (Jiangsu), and 
municipal  (Yancheng)  governments.  An  understanding  was  reached  on  the  PPTA  impact, 
outcome, implementation arrangements, cost estimates, and consultant’s terms of reference. 
The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
3.  Jiangsu  province  lies  in  the  east  of  the  PRC  facing  the  Yellow  Sea  with  a  1,040 
kilometers coastline. The total wetland area within the province, one of the largest coastal 
wetlands in Asia, is about 4 million hectares (ha) or 39% of the total area of the province. It 
includes 1.74 million ha of natural wetlands and 2.26 million ha of artificial wetlands.  
 
4.  With  an  area  of  1.5  million  ha,  Yancheng  municipality,  in  northern  Jiangsu,  is  the 
province’s second largest municipality (even larger than Nanjing, the provincial capital). It has a 
population of 8.1 million and is relatively underdeveloped. Three of its nine counties are ranked 
as provincial poverty counties.2 
 
5.  About 70% of Jiangsu’s coastal wetlands are located in Yancheng. The 453,000 ha, 
stretch for about 580 kilometers along the coast and cover about 30% of the municipality, 
comprising intertidal mudflats, creeks, salt marshes, and reed beds. Yancheng wetlands are 
located in the Huanghuai Delta, one of the four largest deltas in the PRC. It borders the Yellow 
Sea in the east, and its upstream Hongzehu lake catchment is downstream of the Huai river 
basin.  
 
6.  From  a  biodiversity  perspective,  the  two  most  important  areas  are  the  Yancheng 
National Nature Reserve for Rare Birds (YNNRB) and Dafeng Milu (David’s Deer) National 
Nature Reserve (DMNNR). In recognition of the uniqueness of these wetland ecosystems and 
the species biodiversity that they harbor, the two reserves are listed in the Ramsar Convention 
and the United Nations Educational, Scientific, and Cultural Organization’s World Network of 
Biosphere Reserves. The YNNRB is very rich in biodiversity, containing 480 plant, 370 bird, 281 
fish,  48  mammal,  and  45  amphibian  species.  Twelve  animal  species  are  included  in  the 
country’s first-ranked protection priority, and 29 bird species are listed in the International Union 
of Conservation Nature Red List of Threatened Species. The YNNRB is famous for the Red-
Crowned Crane (Grus Japonensis). About 1,000 cranes, or 60% of the world’s total, migrate 
every winter to the YNNRB.

2   
7.  The wetlands of Jiangsu provide important ecosystem services. Local livelihoods are 
sustained through the capture and culture of marine and estuarine plant (e.g., reeds), and fish 
species. Wetland plants slow the flow of rivers and the mudflats absorb wave energy from the 
Yellow  Sea,  thereby  controlling  coastal  erosion.  Wetlands  also  improve  water  quality  by 
absorbing some of the household and industry waste that is rapidly increasing in Yancheng 
municipality. 
 
8.  Yancheng’s wetlands, despite their local, national, and global significance, have been 
under threat. These threats include the following: 
 
(i)  Land reclamation and conversion have significantly altered the ecology of the 
wetlands. Reclamation of the intertidal and lower shore marshlands has involved 
the construction of dikes for aquaculture and food crops. Conversion of the upper 
tidal marshlands has involved the clearing of the wetlands for crop production. A 
large part of the experimental and buffer zones have either been reclaimed or 
converted, which has effectively reduced the habitat area suitable for wildlife. 
(ii)  The construction of roads and dikes inside the core zone and in the buffer and 
experimental  zones  has  already  altered  the  hydrology  of  the  YNNRB  and 
DMNNR. These structures have “compartmentalized” significant portions of the 
reserves and prevent the natural flow of water.  
(iii)  Alien species, such as Spartina alterniflora, originally introduced to stabilize the 
mudflats have expanded rapidly over a large area of the YNNRB and DMNNR 
and into natural salt marshes.3 
(iv)  Increasing pollution loads generated in the upstream areas of the many rivers 
crossing the wetlands contribute to acute pollution of the tideland, the offshore 
sandbars, and the nearby sea. It also has potentially far-reaching effects on 
declines in water flow and sediment from the rivers. 
 
9.  Yancheng coastal ecosystem is a mosaic of diverse coastal habitats and users. Its’ 
management and protection involves many different sectors with many conflicting interests and 
policies. Sustainable wetland planning and management can be achieved when all stakeholders 
are united and engage in a collaborative process to define problems and possible solutions. 
Significant barriers preventing the development of integrated management for the valuable 
ecosystems in Yancheng include the following: 
  
(i)  No specific wetland regulations exist to balance wetland conservation with other 
conflicting activities including agriculture, industry, and urban development. 
(ii)  No  ecosystem  services  and  the  potential  to  improve  downstream  water 
conditions (like the Majiadao wetland area) are recognized to provide incentives 
for relatively poor upstream users to internalize downstream costs.  
(iii)  Current  financial  sources  from  each  level  of  government  are  insufficient  to 
support wetland conservation, particularly in terms of compensating farmers who 
will be banned from farming or fishing within the wetland areas.

(iv)  Technical  guidance  and  services  for  ecotourism  development  in  natural  and 
artificial wetlands are inadequate, and technical standards and procedures to 
ensure sustainable ecotourism development are insufficient.  
(v)  Lack of local enforcement of environmental laws has led many enterprises or 
farmers to assume that direct discharge to waterways is the only solution.  
(vi)  Lack  of  cooperation  between  responsible  agencies  and  lack  of  coordinated 
institutional arrangements result in different agencies promoting different ways of 
natural conservation through different financial sources. 
 
10.  The governments of Jiangsu province and Yancheng municipality are fully aware of 
these problems, and understand the need to urgently address them. In recent years, with 
acceleration of urbanization and industrialization, these governments have been extensively 
discussing how to improve coordination of wetland functions and to integrate management of 
wetland protection, biodiversity conservation, and watershed management. Improved alternative 
livelihood  options  for  resource  users  are  emphasized  as  an  integral  part  of  the  wetland 
protection  strategy.  The  positive  sign  of  all  of  these  discussions  is  the  development  of 
ecotourism, which is becoming an increasingly important sector for Jiangsu province, and in 
particular, Yancheng municipality. 
 
11.  Promoting environmental improvement is one of the strategic priorities in the country 
strategy and program update (2006–2008) for ADB operations in the PRC.4 The proposed 
Project will address (i) threats to the ecological integrity of the coastal ecosystems and their 
ability to support globally-significant plant and animal species, and (ii) ecosystem services that 
are important to the local economy. Management plans will be prepared or updated through an 
inclusive process to guide the interventions in the core, buffer, and experimental zones. 
  
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
12.  The impact of the PPTA is improved management of wetlands, natural resources, and 
environmental sustainability in YMG. The outcome will be a sound project design for integrated 
conservation  and  development  of  Yancheng  coastal  and  upstream  ecosystems  and  its 
watersheds (biodiversity, water, and forests). The PPTA will assist the Government in preparing 
a  project  based  on  the  YMG’s  initial  proposals  to  address  the  technical,  financial,  and 
institutional barriers. The Project is expected to transform wetland conservation through the 
sustainable  implementation  of  ecotourism  by  integrating  it  with  biodiversity  conservation, 
sustainable  resource  management,  improved  ecotourism  service,  and  strengthened 
environmental governance.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities  
13.  The PPTA outputs will include (i) sector situation analysis, and institutional and technical 
assessments  including  a  comprehensive  assessment  and  action  plans  for  sustaining  the 
biodiversity  of  the  coastal  and  upstream  areas;  (ii)  development  of  an  integrated  plan  for 
Yancheng wetland conservation, a multisector participatory plan, and a sustainable livelihood 
plan,  based  on  which  the  project  rationale  and  approach  as  well  as  a  preliminary  list  of 
subprojects  will  be  identified;  and  (iii)  formulation  of  an  investment  project  with  detailed

subproject  analysis  covering  technical,  environmental,  economic,  financial,  and  social 
perspectives.  
 
14.  The PPTA will be implemented in two phases using a participatory approach. During the 
first  phase,  the  consultant  team  will  (i)  conduct  assessments  of  sector  policy,  institutions, 
strategies, and plans; (ii) appraise the project proposals from YMG; and (iii) confirm the project 
rationale, scope, and approach. During the second phase, in consultation with the stakeholders, 
the consultant team will prepare a comprehensive feasibility report. The report will cover in 
detail the project impact, outcome, outputs, and activities—including financial, economic, social, 
and environmental safeguards; relevant sector analysis; role and institutional capacity of key 
participating agencies; procurement; implementation arrangements; and poverty status, gender, 
good governance, and private sector development. Throughout both phases, ADB’s project 
performance management system guidelines will be followed and this will ultimately be reflected 
in the project design and monitoring framework, which will be developed based on effective 
stakeholder participation and guided by the problem and objectives analysis. Key activities for 
each output are included in the PPTA design and monitoring framework (Appendix 1). The initial 
poverty and social analysis is in Appendix 2. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The total cost of the PPTA is estimated at $800,000 equivalent (Appendix 3). ADB will 
finance  $650,000  equivalent  on  a  grant  basis  from  the  ADB  technical  assistance  funding 
program. The Government will contribute $150,000 in-kind for office space, counterpart staff, 
site transportation, and other services.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  YMG will be the Executing Agency. A multiagency municipal leading group5 will be 
established to serve as the steering committee. The group will provide overall guidance to the 
PPTA. Specifically, its functions are to (i) assist in overseeing the preparation of the investment 
plan; (ii) review the selection criteria for subprojects; (iii) ensure municipal, provincial, and 
central  government  institutional  coordination;  and  (iv)  assist  the  technical  assistance 
management office (TMO) and consultants to secure all the internal approvals pertaining to land 
acquisition and other necessary safeguards, etc.  
 
17.  The Government has designated the Yancheng Development and Reform Committee as 
the  lead  agency  to  oversee  PPTA  implementation.  A  TMO  will  be  established  in  YMG 
comprising representatives of Yancheng Development and Reform Committee and the financial, 
environmental, forestry, and tourism bureaus. The TMO will (i) facilitate coordination among the 
concerned agencies in YMG, PPTA consultants, and ADB; (ii) formulate selection criteria for the 
subprojects;  (iii)  provide  access  to  data  and  other  information  required  for  sector  and 
institutional assessments, and project formulation and development; (iv) prepare and submit the 
subproject  proposals  and  feasibility  study  reports,  the  report  on  environmental  impact 
assessments, and resettlement (including compensation and alternative livelihoods) plans for 
the subprojects; (v) assist in assessing training needs and conducting necessary surveys; and 
(vi) ensure the active participation of the major stakeholders during PPTA implementation.  
 
                                                 
5  The members of the leading group are from the bureaus of finance, planning, tourism, ocean and fishery, tideland 
resources development, environmental protection, water resources, forestry, YNNRB, DMNNR, and the four 
Yancheng counties Dafeng, Dongtai, Funing, and Sheyang.

5
18.  The TMO will also be responsible for carrying out preliminary surveys on the biodiversity 
and wetlands in the project areas including (i) wetland characteristics and their development 
over time (habitats, species, vegetation, human settlement and activities, water flows, depth, 
quality, and sedimentation); (ii) a land use inventory (type and area covered by wetlands, 
agriculture, industry, and urban areas) to provide the background information to develop a 
conservation policy framework; and (iii) socioeconomic information, including projections based 
on current plans (population in wetland areas, land reclamation and conversion, agricultural 
intensification,  aquaculture,  urbanization,  industrial  development,  tourism  and  recreation 
demand,  water  management  and  drainage  regime,  and  pollution  sources).  The  TMO  will 
establish a technical task force to assist the TMO in selecting the subprojects, and providing 
guidance to the qualified design institute for the preparation of the subproject feasibility studies, 
and environmental and resettlement reports. 
 
19.  The subproject selection criteria will include (i) consistency with the national, provincial, 
and  municipal  objectives  of  the  11th  Five-Year  Plan  on  Environmental  Protection;  
(ii) demonstration of linkages to effectively contribute to reducing the main causes of wetland 
degradation;  (iii)  adoption  of  reversible  restoration  approaches,  especially  creek  and  river 
straightening, and dredging; (iv) viablility, i.e., participating enterprises or entities having sound 
historical financial performance; and (v) minimum needs for resettlement. The current proposal 
needs  to  be  refined  to  sharpen  the  focus  of  wetland  and  biodiversity  conservation,  and 
demonstrate the clear contributions of upstream activities to the restoration of wetlands and 
habitats of animal and plant species that are mainly in the coastal areas.  
 
20.  Given the nature and activities of the Project, Global Environmental Facility cofinancing 
will be sought to enhance the global environmental benefits. It will include the design of the 
ensuing grant-financing investment to complement the ADB loan-financed project.   
 
21.  The PPTA will be carried out by a firm. It will require international consultants for 12 
person-months  and  national  consultants  for  45  person-months.  The  draft  outline  terms  of 
reference for consultants are in Appendix 4. The consultants will be selected and engaged in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended from time to 
time). ADB will select and engage consultants on the basis of the quality of their proposals and 
the cost of the services to be provided (with a quality cost ratio of 80:20), following simplified 
technical proposal procedures. YMG will procure office equipment in accordance with ADB’s 
Procurement Guidelines (2007, as amended from time to time). The consultants will submit (i) 
an inception report, 4 weeks after commencement of services; (ii) an interim progress report at 
appropriate stages of PPTA implementation; (iii) a draft final report, 20 weeks after PPTA 
commencement; and (iv) a final report, 2 weeks after incorporating YMG and ADB comments.6 
The PPTA will commence in February 2008 and be completed in July 2008. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $650,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  preparing  the  Jiangsu  Yancheng 
Wetlands Protection Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
1.  Based on the country poverty assessment, the country partnership strategy, and the sector analysis, describe how 
the project would directly or indirectly contribute to poverty reduction and how it is linked to the poverty reduction 
strategy of the partner country. 
 
The Project is expected to enhance sustainable use and conservation of the wetlands in Yancheng, while reducing 
rural poverty by establishing integrated wetland management. The Project directly contributes to poverty reduction by 
(i) targeting the poor in one of the more underdeveloped areas within the province that suffers from high income 
inequality; (ii) reducing social vulnerability by promoting sustainable use of natural resources, which are the primary 
source of income for local communities; and (iii) vitalizing the local economy and developing alternative means of 
income generation by introducing ecotourism in collaboration with the private sector.  
 
The Project is aligned with the PRC’s 11th Five-Year Plan 2006–2010, which aims at balanced, equitable, and 
sustainable development. The Project directly addresses the two central issues of income equality reduction and 
environmental protection.  
 
B.  Targeting Classification          
1.  Select the targeting classification of the project: 
 
 General Intervention    Individual or Household (TI-H);  Geographic (TI-G);  Nonincome MDGs (TI-M1, M2, etc.) 
 
 2.    Explain the basis for the targeting classification:  
 
The Project is expected to conserve the coastal and upstream ecosystem, while reducing rural poverty and promoting 
environmental sustainability by establishing an integrated wetland management system in Yancheng municipality.   
 
C.  Poverty Analysis 
 
1.    If the project is classified as TI-H, or if it is policy-based, what type of poverty impact analysis is needed?  
       
  The Project is classified as “general intervention.”  
 
2.  What resources are allocated in the PPTA/due diligence? 
 
Two specialists, a sustainable livelihood and social development specialist and resettlement specialist, in consultation 
with other experts, will review social, gender, and poverty impact assessments to ensure that the Project does not 
have negative repercussions, and if any, to identify mitigating measures. These specialists will develop strategies to 
improve social inclusion and rural livelihoods using a participatory approach.  
 
3.  If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross subsidy, pro-poor 
governance, and pro-poor growth)? 
 
The Project will be designed to (i) reduce social vulnerability through the promotion of sustainable use of natural 
resources, and (ii) vitalize the local economy and develop alternative means of income generation through the 
introduction of ecotourism in collaboration with the private sector.

II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
 
A.   Initial Social Analysis 
  Based on existing information: 
 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit from the 
project? 
 
The primary beneficiaries are the local communities, which are primarily poor and use natural resources from the 
wetlands for their living. The process and outcome of the Project will benefit the poor in several ways. First, an 
inclusive participatory approach will be used in the design process. This provides the poor with opportunities to 
provide inputs into critical decision making for natural resource management that has a direct impact on their 
livelihood. Local government officials and consultants will monitor and ensure the quality of participation. Second, 
more managed use of natural resources minimizes their social vulnerability. And finally, planned investments in 
ecotourism as an alternative source of income generation will diversify and improve household income prospects.  
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
 
As communities have long depended on aquaculture and farming, they will not be able to switch quickly to non-
resource-intensive livelihoods. Accordingly, the Project will (i) conduct awareness raising of the community on 
sustainable use of resources, (ii) conduct capacity building on how to minimize adverse environmental impacts, and 
(iii) explore ways to build the community’s capacity to participate in ecotourism as an alternative livelihood.  
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project address 
them? 
 
Two potential constraints are (i) farmers who may be banned from farming or fishing within the buffer zone may 
oppose the Project, and (ii) farmers may reject altering their livelihoods to non-resource-intensive ones thus nullifying 
the potential benefits ecotourism could bring. To address these issues, the project design will include (i) a sustainable 
livelihood plan; (ii) cofinancing program with the Global Environment Facility on a monitoring and evaluation system 
for protected area management; and (iii) partnership with the current United Nations Development Programme/Global 
Environment Facility, which is now focused on awareness and education development for natural conservation. 
 
B.  Consultation and Participation 
       1.   Indicate the potential initial stakeholders.  
Farmer/fisher groups, community-based organizations engaged in natural resources management and conservation, 
and members of the executing and implementing agencies will be the main participants in planning, implementing, 
and evaluating activities. Private sector stakeholders will be consulted to explore potential ecotourism opportunities.  
 
  2.   What type of consultation and participation (C&P) is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g., workshops, 
  community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based organizations, etc.)? 
 
Community members and community-based organizations will be consulted to identify their needs and views on the 
Project, which will then be relayed to the intergovernmental steering committee and the technical assistance 
management office.  
 
3.    What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
              Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision making         Empowerment 
4.    Will a C&P plan be prepared?    Yes          No    Please explain.  
 
Farmers and community consultation and participation are critical to ensure project sustainability. A C&P plan will be 
prepared. 
 
C.  Gender and Development 
1.    What are the key gender issues in the sector/subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project/program? 
 
The two key issues are (i) insufficient or lack of women’s participation in community decision-making process; and
(ii) limited access by  women to employment opportunities and income, thereby exacerbating  women’s social 
vulnerability.  
 
    2.  Does the proposed project/program have the potential to promote gender equality and/or women’s empowerment by

10         Appendix 2 
 improving women’s access to and use of opportunities, services, resources, assets, and participation in decision 
 making?       Yes          No    Please explain.  
 
The Project aims to increase women’s participation in decision-making regarding natural resource management and 
improve their access to employment opportunities by exploring alternative means of livelihood such as ecotourism. In 
so doing, the social development specialist will undertake gender impact assessment and develop a plan to increase 
women’s involvement in the Project in a participatory manner.  
 
   3.    Could the proposed project have an adverse impact on women and/or girls or widen gender inequality? 
           Yes          No    Please explain. 
  
  The Project is not expected to have significant negative impacts; rather it will strengthen women’s opportunities to 
  improve their livelihoods.

Appendix 4  13 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Overall Scope of Work 
 
1.  The project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will be implemented in two phases. 
Phase 1 (3 months) will (i) study sector performance, problems, and opportunities; (ii) conduct a 
poverty and social analysis; (iii) appraise all proposed subprojects; (iv) propose the preliminary 
project  design;  (v)  examine  the  possibilities  for  public-private  partnerships;  (vi)  document 
important lessons; and (vii) formulate the design and monitoring framework for the Project. In   
phase 2 (3 months), an investment proposal for the Project will be prepared. In particular, phase 
2  will  (i)  strengthen  and  finalize  all  necessary  feasibility  studies,  initial  environmental 
examination and/or environmental impact assessment, and resettlement plans; (ii) prepare cost 
estimates and a financing plan; (iii) conduct economic and financial analyses; (iv) conduct an 
institutional analysis for implementation arrangements and capacity development for the Project; 
(v) analyze financial management and develop a consultation and participation plan; and (vi) 
formulate  a  procurement  plan  and  prepare  bidding  documents.  Throughout  these  phases, 
effective stakeholder consultation and participation, and technology transfer will be carried out. 
Provincial workshops and a workshop among the participating counties will be held to ensure 
active  stakeholder  consultation  in  project  preparation,  and  to  transfer  the  technologies 
developed by the PPTA.     
 
B.  Reporting Requirements 
 
2.  The consultants will submit the following reports: (i) an inception report within 4 weeks of 
commencement of the PPTA, (ii) an interim report to be submitted after 12 weeks (at the end of 
phase 1), (iii) a draft final report to be submitted after 20 weeks, and (iv) a final report to be 
submitted at the conclusion of the PPTA. The consultants will submit all reports in English and 
Chinese languages—six copies in each language to the Government, and three copies of the 
English version to the Asian Development Bank (ADB), including one electronic copy on a 
compact disc. 
 
3.  The draft final report will be structured in accordance with ADB’s requirements for the 
report and recommendation of the President, and will cover each topic by chapter sufficiently for 
ADB to finalize the report. The final report will reflect comments made by government agencies, 
ADB, and other relevant parties. 
 
C.  Terms of Reference  
 
4.  The PPTA will be carried out by a team of consultants, engaged through a firm, requiring 
12 person-months of international and 45 person-months of national consulting services. The 
PPTA is expected to start in February 2008 and be completed in July 2008.    
 
5.  Team  Leader  and  Integrated  Ecosystem  Management  Specialist  (international,  
6  person-months).  The  specialist  will  have  postgraduate  qualification  in  biodiversity 
conservation, wetland restoration, hydrology, civil engineering, environmental engineering, or 
related  fields;  and  substantive  experience  in  ecosystem  management,  especially  wetland 
management, and preferably experience in working with governments in the People’s Republic 
of  China  (PRC).  The  team  leader  will  (i)  manage  the  consultant  team  members,  both 
international and national, and lead in formulating and developing the project design and the 
feasibility study for the Project, including (a) undertaking rigorous technical, economic, financial, 
social, and environmental evaluation of the subprojects and the Project; and (b) addressing 
cross-cutting areas of concern (resettlement, environment, poverty, social aspects, gender,

14   Appendix 4 
private  sector  development,  and anticorruption)  for  subprojects  and  the  Project;  (ii)  review 
international best practices on wetland management, draw lessons from previous and current 
wetland restoration, conservation, and development projects; and incorporate the best practices 
and lessons into the project design; (iii) lead the team to conduct key assessments including 
sector  policy,  institutions,  strategies,  plans,  etc.;  (iv)  assist  in  devising  alternative  forest 
plantation  establishment  and  management  strategies  to  meet  different  forest  management 
objectives (e.g., recreation, wildlife management, typhoon protection) including variations in 
species  mix  and  planting  protocols;  (v)  together  with  the  Yancheng  municipal  government 
(YMG), the Executing Agency, and in consultation with stakeholders, identify selection criteria 
for the subproject and/or policy options, and prepare a project design; (vi) coordinate closely 
with the Global Environment Facility (GEF)-related technical support as it relates to the Project; 
and (vii) be responsible for production and timely delivery of inception, midterm, draft final, and 
final reports to ADB and YMG; and provide in a timely manner the draft as well as the final 
feasibility study of the Project to ADB and YMG. The team leader will have overall responsibility 
for quality and consistency of all PPTA outputs in accordance with ADB’s policies, standards, 
and guidelines. 
 
6.  Deputy  Team  Leader  and  Wetland  Management  Specialist  (national,  6  person-
months).  The  expert  will  have  a  postgraduate  qualification  and  technical  background  in 
biodiversity  conservation,  wetland  restoration,  hydrology,  civil  engineering,  environmental 
engineering, or related fields; and at least 10 years related work experience. Preferably the 
expert is familiar with the project area (Jiangsu) wetland and hydrological situation. As deputy 
team leader, the expert  will (i) analyze the efficiency and effectiveness of the institutional 
structure and/or arrangements of central and local governments and the technical managerial 
capabilities and/or staffing pattern of YMG and implementing agencies in planning and using an 
integrated  ecosystem  approach,  interagency  coordination,  project  management  and 
implementation, and post-investment operation and maintenance; (ii) assess the nature and 
forms  of  stakeholder  participation  in  wetland  restoration  and  development,  and  ecosystem 
policy formulation and management, including devolution of management to communities and 
the central role of women; (iii) assess the fairness and consistency in enforcing regulations and 
policies affecting the wetland ecosystems; (iv) assess the capacity of personnel and other 
resources and systems for financial and project management; (v) develop a detailed institutional 
strengthening  and  capacity  building  plan  including  budget;  and  assist  the  team  leader  in 
conducting assessments of sector policy, institutions, strategies, plans, etc.; (vi) develop a 
detailed participatory strategy and action plan to involve major stakeholders, including women in 
project implementation, and monitoring and evaluation; (vii) assist the team leader in overseeing 
the design of the project performance monitoring system; (viii) take the lead role in designing 
and conducting the multistakeholder consultation during project design, and preparation of the 
feasibility study; (ix) help the team leader in production and timely delivery of inception, midterm, 
draft final, and final reports to ADB and YMG; and (x) help the team leader to ensure quality and 
consistency of all PPTA outputs in accordance with ADB’s policies, standards, and guidelines. 
 
7.  Economists (international, 2 person-months; national, 3 person-months). The experts 
will  have  postgraduate  qualifications  in  economics  and  technical  background  in 
environmental/natural  resource  economics,  and  at  least  10  years  of  work  experience  in 
designing and assessing development projects using integrated ecosystem management. The 
consultants  will  (i)  review  and  evaluate  the  Government’s  wetland  conservation  and 
development plan as well as the proposed subprojects in terms of (a) appropriateness of the 
rationale, goal, and objectives; and strategy and approach to achieve the goal and objectives;  
(b)  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  proposed  subprojects  and  policies  as  well  as  funding 
resources;  and  (c)  efficiency  and  effectiveness  of  the  overall  plan  in  contributing  to  the 
development objectives of ADB; (ii) prepare detailed economic analysis in accordance with

Appendix 4  15 
ADB’s Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects1 by using COSTAB or other suitable 
programs; (iii) assist the team leader and deputy team leader in analyzing market performance, 
assessing policies and regulatory measures that impact on the ecological functioning of the 
wetlands, and analyzing financial structures; and recommend to YMG and ADB economically- 
sound subprojects; (iv) assist YMG in improving and developing the wetland restoration and 
development  plan;  (v)  provide  appropriate  pricing  and  other  policy  frameworks  for  the 
subprojects, including tariffs for national parks and other ecotourism sites; and (vi) assist the 
team leader and deputy team leader in preparing various progress reports. The consultants will 
have  overall  responsibility  for  quality  and  consistency  in  preparing  the  detailed  economic 
analysis in accordance with ADB’s guidelines. 
 
8.  Financial Specialist (national, 5 person-months). The expert should have an academic 
degree in business administration or accounting, at least 7 years of work experience in financial 
analysis  and  financial  management  assessments  (FMAs)  of  development  projects,  and 
extensive knowledge of financial management operations in the PRC. The consultant will (i) in 
coordination  with  the  economist,  ensure  consistency  in  approach,  methodology,  and  basic 
assumptions; and carry out financial evaluation of the subprojects and the Project, and assess 
their financial sustainability; (ii) prepare project cost estimates, financing plan, and financial 
projections; and assess the veracity of government counterparts, beneficiary contributions, and 
cofinancing,  where  applicable,  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  for  the  Financial 
Governance and Management of Investment Projects Financed by ADB (2002); (iii) undertake 
FMAs for YMG and the implementing agencies, which should include a review of (a) corporate 
planning and budgetary control, (b) financial and management accounting, (c) cost accounting,  
(d) internal control and audit system, and (e) data processing (iv) provide a summary of the 
FMAs  that  includes  an  evaluation  of  the  adequacy  of  the  agency’s  financial  management 
arrangements for project implementation and operation, as well as identification of financial 
management risks and suggested mitigating measures; (v) design a fund flow mechanism and 
identify  appropriate  ADB  disbursement  procedures;  (vi)  determine  financial  reporting 
mechanisms, requirements, and timetable; as well as appropriate procurement, disbursement, 
and auditing arrangements that are in accordance with ADB’s guidelines; (vii) determine the 
performance  indicators,  and  provide  inputs  in  the  sector  and  institutional  assessments  in 
improving the wetland restoration and development plan; and (viii) assist the team leader and 
the deputy team leader in preparing various progress reports. The consultant will have the 
overall responsibility for quality and consistency in preparing the detailed financial analysis in 
accordance with ADB’s guidelines. 
 
9.  Protected  Area  Management  Specialists  (international, 2 person-months; national,  
5 person-months). The experts will have a university qualification in the related subjects and 
extensive experience in wetland national park development and management, preferably in a 
similar environment as the project area. The consultant will (i) review international and national 
experiences in developing and managing national parks, especially wetland conservation parks; 
(ii) in close collaboration with other specialists, assess institutional and organizational capacity 
and environmental and financial feasibility of developing the national park(s) in the project area 
on  the  basis  of  extensive  stakeholder  consultation;  (iii)  develop  a  detailed  conservation, 
development, and management plan of the national park(s), and assist the team leader and 
deputy team leader in developing institutional strengthening and a capacity-building plan and 
budget for this plan; and (iv) assist the team leader and deputy team leader in preparing 
relevant reports.  
 
                                                 
1  ADB. 1997. Guidelines for the Economic Analysis of Projects. Manila.

10.  Agroforestry Ecology Specialist (national, 5 person-months). The expert will have a 
university qualification in the related subjects and technical qualifications in forestry economics, 
ecology, or related fields; and at least 7 years of work experience in integrated natural resource 
management and ecological restoration planning. The consultant will (i) assess the technical, 
environmental, economic, and social merits of the reforestation subproject options proposed in 
the project area; (ii) evaluate institutional arrangements and policy measures that support the 
implementation  of  agroforestry  subprojects,  maximize  stakeholder  ownership,  ensure 
affordability, and improve the water quantity and quality of the project area; (iii) evaluate the 
counterpart funding requirements and financial capacity of concerned local governments, and 
help with the benefit-cost analysis of these subprojects; (iv) assist the team leader and deputy 
team leader in preparing the relevant reports.  
 
11.  Water Resources/Hydraulic Engineering Specialist (national, 3 person-months). The 
specialist will have a university qualification in water resources or hydraulic engineering; and 
technical  background  in  hydraulic  engineering  or  related  fields  of  water  engineering,  and 
groundwater or surface water hydrology planning and design in similar wetland environments as 
Jiangsu; and at least 10 years of work experience in planning, appraisal, and technical design of 
water resource projects. The consultant will (i) assess the hydraulic engineering requirements 
for wetland restoration and development; (ii) review and appraise the preliminary design and 
engineering  feasibility  of  the  proposed  subprojects  and  recommend  technically-  and 
environmentally-feasible and cost-effective alternatives; (iii) evaluate the counterpart funding 
requirements and financial capacity of concerned local governments, and help with the benefit-
cost analysis of the subprojects; (iv) review the technical and environmental impacts of the 
relevant  proposed  subprojects;  and  (v)  assist  the  team  leader  and  deputy  team  leader  in 
preparing relevant reports.  
 
12.  Sustainable  Livelihood  and  Social  Development  Specialist  (national,  5  person- 
months).  The  specialist  will  have  postgraduate  qualifications  in  development  economics, 
ecology, or related social science fields; and demonstrate at least 7 years of work experience in 
developing innovative sustainable livelihood activities and undertaking poverty and social, and 
gender  analysis  and  plans.  The  consultant  will  (i)  undertake  a  resource  endowment, 
socioeconomic needs, and gender assessments of poverty villages in project sites; (ii) conduct 
poverty and social impact assessments of the proposed Project in accordance with ADB’s 
Poverty Handbook2 and Handbook on Social Analysis; 3 (iii) together with the economist, help 
with the distribution analysis by conducting an assessment of whether the project benefits will 
flow primarily to poor/nonpoor consumers and whether any poor or vulnerable groups will be 
excluded; (iv) conduct gender assessments in the project area, analyze the Project from a 
gender  perspective,  and  develop  project  components  and  implementation  mechanisms  to 
ensure women’s participation in the Project; (v) provide recommendations on how to make the 
project design more pro-poor, socially inclusive, and sustainable; and develop a gender plan 
and a sustainable livelihood plan for the poverty villages in project sites using a participatory 
approach; in coordination with the tourism expert, suggest pilot livelihood projects that can be 
tried  out  in  cooperation  with  local  governments  and  the  private  sector  in  the  project  site;  
(vi)  assist  the  resettlement  and  environmental  impact  assessment  experts  in  identifying 
mitigating measures; and (vii) assist the team leader and deputy team leader in preparing 
various progress reports.  
 
13.  Resettlement  Specialist  (national,  4  person-months).  The  specialist  should  have 
relevant qualifications in social sector surveys and extensive work experience in designing 
                                                 
2  ADB. 2006. Poverty Handbook. Manila.   
3  ADB. 2007. Handbook on Social Analysis. Manila.

Appendix 4  17 
resettlement plans in the PRC for ADB projects. The consultant will (i) review and prepare the 
draft resettlement plans in compliance with ADB’s Handbook on Resettlement;4 (ii) determine 
and document in the resettlement plans the extent to which the project design has avoided or 
minimized land acquisition and displacement of people and businesses; (iii) define categories 
for  impact  and  compensation  eligibility  of  affected  people,  prepare  an  entitlements  matrix 
(consistent with the PRC’s Land Administration Law and other pertinent public regulations and 
ADB’s policy on involuntary resettlement), and prepare village economic rehabilitation plans, 
where  applicable;  (iv)  assist  YMG  and  relevant  local  government  officials  in  preparing  a 
resettlement implementation schedule consistent with the project schedule; and to consult with 
the affected communities, local leaders, proponents, and stakeholders; (v) review the capacity 
of  the  concerned  local  governments  to  implement  resettlement  plans  and  provide 
recommendations for improvements; (vi) based on individual subproject resettlement plans, 
prepare a summary resettlement plan for the Project in accordance with ADB’s guidelines; and  
(vii) assist the team leader and deputy team leader in preparing various progress reports.  
 
14.  Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) Specialists (international, 2 person-months; 
national,  4  person-months).  The  experts  will  have  postgraduate  degrees  in  environment 
economics, natural resource economics, or related fields; and at least 7 years work experience 
in  developing  EIAs  that  are  consistent  with  ADB’s  environment  policy  and  environmental 
assessment guidelines. The consultant will (i) provide the initial EIA of the current environmental 
situation of the project areas; (ii) assist YMG and the implementing agencies in validating and/or 
confirming the initial categorization of the Project; for a category A project, the expert will assist 
YMG and the implementing agencies in developing the comprehensive EIA reports and the 
environmental management plans; for a category B project, summary EIA reports of subprojects 
will be needed; the expert will develop the terms of reference for the EIA, provide technical 
support to YMG and the implementing agencies in developing reports, review procedures, 
public consultations and disclosures, and environmental management plans; (iii) submit to EIA 
reports that evaluate the environmental viability and sustainability of the subprojects and project 
as a whole, and identify environmental considerations that may form part of the loan covenants; 
(iv) provide indicators for the project performance monitoring system; and (v) assist the team 
leader and deputy team leader in preparing various environmental progress reports.  
 
15.  Institutional Strengthening and Capacity Building Specialist (national, 5 person- 
months). The specialist will have a postgraduate degree in related fields and at least 7 years 
work  experience  in  environmental  regulatory  and  legislative  experiences  in  the  PRC.  The 
consultant will (i) assess the capacity and effectiveness of agencies and other stakeholders in 
addressing  adverse  environmental  impacts;  (ii)  design  the  institutional  strengthening  and 
capacity building component of the Project; (iii) assess the existing environmental regulations 
and legislations in the project area; (iv) review tourism development plans, land use plans, and 
social and economic development plans in the project area; (v) assess the institutional and 
organizational  capacity  of  mainstreaming  biodiversity  protection  in  the  plans;  (vi)  provide 
detailed recommendations of mainstreaming biodiversity conservation in the plans in the project 
area; and (vii) assist the team leader and deputy team leader in preparing various progress 
reports.
